articles.headline: JetBlue Starts Selling Blankets and Pillows
articles.snippet: No more free pillows and blankets on JetBlue Airways, but they will be sold for $7 on flights over two hours.
articles.abstract: No more free pillows and blankets on JetBlue Airways, but they will be sold for $7 on flights over two hours.

articles.headline: Inflation Takes Steam Out of Rise in Spending
articles.snippet: Consumer spending increased 0.6 percent in June, but prices rose 0.8 percent, the government reported, indicating months of challenges to come.
articles.abstract: Consumer spending increased 0.6 percent in June, but prices rose 0.8 percent, the government reported, indicating months of challenges to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers spent more in June, but only because the things they bought cost more.

articles.headline: Ambush in China Raises Concerns as Olympics Near
articles.snippet: Officials labeled the attack terrorism and suggested the culprits were from a group seeking independence for China’s Uighur minority.
articles.abstract: Officials labeled the attack terrorism and suggested the culprits were from a group seeking independence for China’s Uighur minority.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Two men armed with knives and explosives ambushed a military police unit in China’s majority Muslim northwest on Monday. State media reported the attackers killed 16 officers and wounded 16 others, likely making it the deadliest outburst of ethnic violence in China since at least the early 1990s.

articles.headline: Bosnia Fugitive Is Hero to Some, Butcher to Others
articles.snippet: Ratko Mladic, accused in the massacre at Srebrenica, is now the most wanted fugitive from the Balkan conflict.
articles.abstract: Ratko Mladic, accused in the massacre at Srebrenica, is now the most wanted fugitive from the Balkan conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOZINOVICI, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Ratko Mladic, accused in Europe’s worst massacre since World War II and now the most wanted fugitive for the atrocities in the Balkan wars, grew up in this poor, remote mountain village that is blanketed with crows. Here, as in many places where Serbs live, his military prowess, his undeniable suffering and the imponderable scale of the crimes he is accused of have made him as much a national myth as a man.

articles.headline: Booming China Suddenly Worries That a Slowdown Is Taking Hold
articles.snippet: Growth in China is expected to slip a couple of percentage points below the double digit threshold over the coming year, relieving inflationary pressure but undermining global growth.
articles.abstract: Growth in China is expected to slip a couple of percentage points below the double digit threshold over the coming year, relieving inflationary pressure but undermining global growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Many Chinese have been expecting a post-Olympics economic slowdown, but it has already started and the Games have not even begun.

articles.headline: On Wall St., Reputation Is Fragile
articles.snippet: The story of the resignation of Steven Rattner, a managing director at Credit Suisse, started with an extramarital affair and ended with an Internet vendetta.
articles.abstract: The story of the resignation of Steven Rattner, a managing director at Credit Suisse, started with an extramarital affair and ended with an Internet vendetta.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, Credit Suisse announced the resignation of Steven Rattner, a managing director and the head of its private equity arm, DLJ Merchant Banking.

articles.headline: At Freddie Mac, Chief Discarded Warning Signs
articles.snippet: A 2004 memo warned of problematic loans at the mortgage giant, but the questionable practices continued.
articles.abstract: A 2004 memo warned of problematic loans at the mortgage giant, but the questionable practices continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the mortgage giant Freddie Mac rejected internal warnings that could have protected the company from some of the financial crises now engulfing it, according to more than two dozen current and former high-ranking executives and others.

articles.headline: Pickens Plan Stirs Debate, and Qualms
articles.snippet: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the billionaire Texas oilman, has mounted a campaign to launch a national debate about the use of natural gas in cars and trucks.
articles.abstract: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the billionaire Texas oilman, has mounted a campaign to launch a national debate about the use of natural gas in cars and trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: California automobile dealers report long waiting lists for a Honda Civic that runs on natural gas. In Utah, where natural gas is especially cheap, drivers are scouring the Internet for vehicles that burn it. In Washington, members of Congress are eagerly filing bills favoring natural gas cars.
